theme: Bar staff upsell + local promos on slow nights

avatar_style.persona: Friendly, no-nonsense bartender in their late 20s or early 30s. Looks like they could be at the end of a shift.
avatar_style.wardrobe: Dark t-shirt or bar-branded polo, maybe a half-apron.
avatar_style.setting: A dimly lit, cozy neighborhood bar, either just before opening or after closing. Looks authentic.

script.speaker: host
script.line: It’s a slow Tuesday. You've wiped the same spot on the bar three times. Here's something useful to do.
script.broll_cue: Host leans on a clean bar, looking bored but friendly at the camera.

script.speaker: host
script.line: See that TV in the corner? It's usually just playing muted news. We use it to actually move product.
script.broll_cue: Quick pan to a TV in the bar showing a generic news channel or sports highlights, muted.

script.speaker: host
script.line: It’s an app called Trillboards. First, you just pull up a QR code on the TV and scan it with your phone to pair it. Takes 30 seconds.
script.broll_cue: Host holds up phone. Screen-recording inlay shows scanning a QR code from screen.trillboards.com on the TV.

script.speaker: host
script.line: Then you pick a playlist. We use the 'Bar Specials' one. It cycles through our high-margin cocktails, appetizer deals, and promotes our trivia night.
script.broll_cue: Phone screen shows scrolling through templates and selecting 'Bar Specials'. The TV in the background changes to a professional-looking 'Cocktail of the Week' card.

script.speaker: host
script.line: We also add in a few paid promos from local spots, like the yoga studio down the street. They're happy to reach people here.
script.broll_cue: TV rotates to a card that says 'First Class Free @ Downtown Yoga'. Host gives a slight nod.

script.speaker: host
script.line: It can bring in an extra ten to forty bucks a day for the venue, and people actually order the specials. Just get the okay from your manager first, obviously.
script.broll_cue: Close up on the host, speaking sincerely. Final shot of the TV rotating between a drink special and a local event.

caption_overlay.text: It’s a slow Tuesday. You've wiped the same spot on the bar three times.
See that TV in the corner? We use it to actually move product.
It’s an app called Trillboards. You just pull up a QR code on the TV and scan it with your phone.
Then you pick a playlist. It cycles through our high-margin cocktails and promotes our trivia night.
We also add in a few paid promos from local spots, like the yoga studio down the street.
It can bring in an extra ten to forty bucks a day. Just get the okay from your manager first.

secondary: Close-up on a freshly wiped, clean bar top.

trillboards_touchpoints.action: Scan a QR code from screen.trillboards.com with the app.
trillboards_touchpoints.why_it_helps: It's a one-time, 30-second setup that requires no hardware or technical skill.

trillboards_touchpoints.action: Select a pre-made template like 'Bar Specials'.
trillboards_touchpoints.why_it_helps: Instantly populates the screen with relevant, professional-looking content without any design work.

trillboards_touchpoints.action: Swap out a special or event card from the phone.
trillboards_touchpoints.why_it_helps: Keeps content fresh and relevant (e.g., 86 an item, add a new beer) without needing a computer.

constraints_and_risks: Must have permission from the venue owner or manager before setting up.
Earnings are not guaranteed; they depend on location, foot traffic, and advertiser demand.
Be considerate: only accept local promos that don't compete with the bar's own offerings (e.g., no promos for another bar).

metrics_hypothesis.shareability_notes: Highly shareable among service industry workers (bartenders, servers, managers) via group chats and DMs. Relatable problem, practical solution.

alt_hooks: Your bar has a TV. Here's how to make it actually earn its keep.
This TV is making more than just tips on a slow night.
Turn dead airtime on your bar's TV into your best upsell tool.

rights_and_clearance_notes: Requires location release from the bar owner. Any background music must be from a licensed library (e.g., Artlist, Epidemic Sound). Avoid showing recognizable patrons without a release.
